awd_titl_txt: A Spectroscopic and Computational Structure-Function Study of Biosilicification Peptides
awd_abstract_narration:
Metal oxides including silicon oxide (SiO2, silica) and titanium oxide (TiO2, titania) have numerous applications as insulators, textile coatings, catalysts, chemical decontaminants, solar cell components, medical/dental implants and chemical sensors. Industrial synthesis and morphological control of these important hard materials requires extremes in temperature, pressure and pH and are thus energetically demanding. In contrast, biological organisms accomplish impressive feats of mineral oxide production with precise control over morphology that is virtually unmatched by industrial approaches, and do so at ambient temperature, pressure and at physiological pH in a process called biomineralization. Biogenic silica (i.e. biosilica) is produced in gigaton quantities annually by the diatom, a marine microalgae characterized by an intricately decorated cell wall that is composed of organic material and silica. Diatoms take in silicon in dissolved form, and convert it to elaborate silica structures, in an as yet poorly understood process where proteins and other organic polymers are believed play important roles as catalysts and templates for silica formation. This research is aimed at understanding the specific roles played by proteins that are used by diatoms to form silica, with the immediate goal of making smaller, and less expensive molecules that imitate the diatom's ability to control silica formation under mild conditions. The long-term goal is to use similarly designed small molecules to effect the controlled formation of non-biological oxides like TiO2.  This project will provide training for young scientists and engineers in the use of spectroscopic and computational techniques to elucidate structure-function relationships in biomaterials.

The research will utilize solid state NMR (ssNMR), advanced non-equilibrium molecular dynamics (MD) computations, and novel chemical synthesis techniques, to determine the molecular structural properties and interactions that underlie the silicifying activities of naturally-occurring peptides. Initial study will be focused on modified and unmodified forms of the R5 peptide, derived from the bio-silicification protein silaffin of the diatom species Cylindrotheca fusiformis. Specific questions that this research project will address include: 1. Do unmodified silicifying peptide domain derived (e.g. R5) assume specific secondary structures that promote peptide-peptide interactions which in turn lead to formation of higher order structures? 2. What is the nature of peptide-silica interactions? 3. How do amino acid modifications influence peptide structure and peptide-peptide interactions in silica, and, most importantly, how do these modifications affect peptide-silica interactions? 4. Can R5, that induce silica formation, also induce formation of non-biological oxides like TiO2. Are the structural principles used by R5 to form silica similar to the principles it uses to form other oxides?  Answers to these questions will provide structure-based principles for the design of peptides and other small molecules that can mimic in vitro the silicifying activities of naturally occurring proteins like silaffin.

por.por_cntn:
Metal oxides including silicon oxide (SiO2, silica) and titantium (IV) oxide (TiO2, titania) have numerous applications as insulators, textile coatings, catalysts, chemical decontaminants, solar cell components, medical/dental implants and chemical sensors. Industrial synthesis and morphological control of these important hard materials requires extremes in temperature, pressure and pH and are thus energetically demanding. In contrast, biological organisms accomplish impressive feats of mineral oxide production with precise control over morphology that is virtually unmatched by industrial approaches, and do so at ambient temperature, pressure and at physiological pH in a process called biomineralization. Biogenic silica (i.e. biosilica) is produced in gigaton quantities annually by the diatom, a marine microalgae characterized by an intricately decorated cell wall that is composed of organic material and silica. Diatoms take in silicon in dissolved form, and convert it to elaborate silica structures, in an as yet poorly understood process where proteins and other organic polymers are believed play important roles as catalysts and templates for silica formation. Our research has aimed at understanding the specific roles played by proteins that are used by diatoms to form silica, with the immediate goal of making smaller, and less expensive molecules that imitate the diatom?s ability to control silica formation under mild conditions. In addition, we extended our studies to the use of similarly designed small molecules to effect the controlled formation of non-biological oxides like TiO2.

We initiated and completed a ssNMR study of the R5 peptide, i.e. (NH2SSKKSGSYSGSKGSKRRILCOOH, derived from the biosilicification protein silaffin of the diatom species Cylindrotheca fusiformis. Although the unmodified R5 peptide and LK14 both precipitate biosilica nanospheres, chemical shift data indicates that R5 is not helically structured in silica and the aggregatory state of R5 in silica is as yet unknown. Prior work also shows R5 is unstructured in solution and the aggregatory state in solution is likewise unresolved. We found that R5 likely aggregates into a micellar-like structure when in contact with silica, which exposes the positively charged lysine residues in the peptide to the negatively charged silica. The peptide likely aggregates using the four amino acid RRIL at its C-terminus.

 

We also completed a study of the impact of amino acid modifications on the R5 silicifying peptide structure/function. The vast majority of materials science-oriented studies of silaffin-derived peptides reported in the literature are performed on unmodified peptides, of which R5 is a prime example. However, silaffin peptides contain numerous amino acid modifications which impact silica morphology. In this aim we will develop and apply novel synthetic methods for incorporating modified amino acids in the R5 peptide. While R5 is able to mediate SiO2 precipitation sans post-translational modifications, it can act as a model system to understand the role of lysine modifications. We explored the effects of amine methylation on specific activity and SiO2 morphology with three R5 variants containing trimethyl-L-lysine residues at positions K3, K4, and both K3 and K4. Our results show that the specific SiO2 -precipitating activity is affected by methylation; specifically, the presence of trimethyl-L-lysine at both positions K3 and K4 reduces the specific activity. Additionally, trimethyl-L-lysine at K4 creates SiO2 precipitates with a more varied size and morphology than wild type R5 or R5 with trimethyl-L-lysine at position K3.

 

Silicifying peptides including LKa14 and silaffin, induce the formation of TiO2 (i.e. titania) from solutions of titanium (IV) bis(ammoniumlactato) dihydroxide (TBALDH). Although oxides of titanium, germanium, gallium, zinc have been precipitated by a variety of organic molecules composites little experimental data has been obtained to date concerning the structural states of peptides and proteins within these composite materials. We used ssNMR and MD methods to determine in titania composites the structures and aggregatory states of the silicifying peptide R5, which precipitates titania nanospheres from TBALDH solutions. We used ssNMR and MD simulations to determine the degree to which the structural properties of R5 in biotitania composites resembles or does not resemble its structure in silica and how this peptide adapts its local secondary structure and possibly the structure of its aggregates to interacting with  a non-native oxide.

We also used saturation transfer solution NMR methods to study the interactions of amino acids and small peptides to TiO2 nanoparticles suspended in gels to avoid gravity sedimentation. These experiments showed that an ensemble of peptide structures exist at surfaces. MD simulations showed the exact distribution of structures is governed by factors like the local surface chemistry, the density of surface hydroxyl groups and the charge on the hydroxyl groups.
